xxl.core.cursors.sources

Class Permutator

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<Integer>
      • xxl.core.cursors.sources.Permutator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<Integer>, Cursor<Integer>

    public class Permutator
extends AbstractCursor<Integer>
    The permutator 'returns' a permutation of a given input array or creates a permutation of integer values from 0 to n by lazy evaluation. With the help of this class the caller is able to get a permutation of every kind of 1-dimensional arrays, especially integer arrays. Furthermore the caller is able to specify his own pseudo random number generator, e.g., with the intention to get a better permutation.

    Example usage (1): 

         Permutator permutator = new Permutator(10);
 
     permutator.open();
 
     while (permutator.hasNext())
         System.out.print(permutator.next() + "; ");
     System.out.flush();
     System.out.println();
 
     permutator.close();
    This example permutes the integer numbers of the interval [0,10[. Therefore a new integer array is created. In this case Java's random number generator generates a stream of pseudo random numbers. The class uses a 48-bit seed, which is modified using a linear congruential formula. (See Donald Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming, Volume 2, Section 3.2.1.) If two instances of the class Random are created with the same seed, and the same sequence of method calls is made for each, they will generate and return identical sequences of numbers. In order to guarantee this property, particular algorithms are specified for the class Random. Each call to next returns one random element of the array. After completely consuming the permutator the result is a complete permutation of the given array.

    Example usage (2): 

         permutator = new Permutator(new int[10], new SecureRandom());
 
     permutator.open();
 
     while (permutator.hasNext())
         System.out.print(permutator.next() + "; ");
     System.out.flush();
     System.out.println();
 
     permutator.close();
    A new permutator is created with the help of a given array containing the integers 0,...,9 and a secure random number generator. In this case the next method calls the nextInt method of the class SecureRandom. This class provides a cryptographically strong pseudo-random number generator (PRNG). After consuming the whole permutator the result is a complete permutation of the given array.

    See Also:
    Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor, Random, SecureRandom

      • Permutator

        public Permutator(int[] array)
        Creates a new permutator backed on the given array. As default pseudo random number generator JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper is used.
        Parameters:
        array - the array the permutation should be fulfilled with.

      • Permutator

        public Permutator(int n,
                  Random random)
        Creates a new permutator by creating an int array using the given parameter n as the array's length. Therefore the permutator's range is [0,n[.
        Parameters:
        n - the integer constant defining the length of an integer array, the permutation should be fulfilled with.
        random - the pseudo random number generator (PRNG).

      • Permutator

        public Permutator(int n)
        Creates a new permutator by creating an integer array using the given parameter n as the array's length. JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper is used as pseudo random number generator.
        Parameters:
        n - the integer constant defining the length of an integer array, the permutation should be fulfilled with.

    • Method Detail

      • open

        public void open()
        Opens the permutator, i.e., signals it to reserve resources, initialize the intern array, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

        Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

        Specified by:
        open in interface Cursor<Integer>
        Overrides:
        open in class AbstractCursor<Integer>

      • hasNextObject

        protected boolean hasNextObject()
        Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
        Specified by:
        hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<Integer>
        Returns:
        true if the permutator has more elements.

      • nextObject

        protected Integer nextObject()
        Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the permutator's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

        Each element of the array will be returned only for one time. Every call to this method swaps two elements in the underlying array: One position to be swapped depends on the given random number generator and is computed with 

             index + random.nextInt(array.length - index)
        The uniformly distributed int value delivered by random's nextInt method lies between 0 (inclusive) and the specified array.length-index (exclusive). The position to be swapped is determined by adding index to this random int value. Thereafter the element located at this position is swapped with array[index].

        Specified by:
        nextObject in class AbstractCursor<Integer>
        Returns:
        the next element in the iteration.
